habitat_description:
Northwest:
Gray-tailed voles are associated with agricultural lands, particularly small grains, sod grasses, permanent pasture, hayfields, old fields, and grassy abandoned areas (Bailey 1936, Goertz 1964, Verts and Carraway 1998). Originally, habitat consisted of large prairies (such as those in the Williamette Valley) maintained by Native Americans (Johannessen et al. 1971) and have established themselves in Coast Range areas previously forested that are now agricultural (Verts and Carraway 1998, Goertz 1964, Maser and Storm 1970). They occur in transportation right-of-ways and recently cleared lands but avoid forested areas (Wilson and Ruff 1999).
